message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows a characteristic finding of congenital rubella syndrome, which can cause patent ductus arteriosus among other congenital defects. None of the other options are commonly associated with rubella.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows a characteristic finding of congenital rubella syndrome, which can cause patent ductus arteriosus among other congenital heart defects. Atrial and ventricular septal defects are less commonly associated with congenital rubella syndrome, while tetralogy of Fallot is not typically associated with it.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows the classic finding of a "salt and pepper" appearance in the retina, which is consistent with congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus is the most common congenital heart defect associated with congenital rubella syndrome. Atrial and ventricular septal defects and Tetralogy of Fallot are also associated with congenital rubella syndrome, but less frequently than patent ductus arteriosus.

Among the possible heart defects, patent ductus arteriosus is the most commonly associated with congenital rubella syndrome.

Patent ductus arteriosus is the most common congenital heart defect associated with rubella syndrome. Atrial septal defect and ventricular septal defect are not typically associated with rubella syndrome, while Tetralogy of Fallot is less commonly associated with it.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows the presence of Roth spots, which are associated with infective endocarditis. The mother had a fever with rash and swollen lymph nodes during gestation, which suggests a possible infection. Among the options, only Patent ductus arteriosus is associated with an increased risk of infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows a "salt and pepper" appearance of the retina, which is a classic finding in congenital rubella syndrome. The most common heart defect associated with this syndrome is patent ductus arteriosus. Therefore, the correct answer is (D). Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, and tetralogy of Fallot are not commonly associated with congenital rubella syndrome.
